body:
Alternatively, supporting uploading a single file in JSON format such as:
```JSON
[
    "Document 1 text",
    "Document 2 text"
]
```

Would also work.

**Edit:**
For example this snippet of code would parse the above JSON:
```python
form_data = json.load(request.FILES['json_file'].file)
    Document.objects.bulk_create(
        [Document(text=entry, project=project) for entry in form_data])
```

There appears to be a gotcha in your rendering code though where even if the document text contains a newline character it is not rendered as such.  Haven't figured out where that occurs yet.

I've created a bare-bones implementation of this second approach utilizing a single JSON file here:
https://github.com/Zerthick/doccano/pull/1

It currently adds a second radio button to allow the user to specify which format file they would like to upload, however this could be changed to infer the format based on the file name extension.

In addition, this method of upload allows documents to contain both newline characters and commas within their text, meaning the rendering of the annotation views should support this behavior.

rename.from: Support importing datasets containing multiple files
rename.to: Support importing datasets in JSON format

body:
Thank you for your proposal! Certainly supporting one-data-one-file format (like jsonl) is good for the data including newline or complex structure.

When supporting this feature, I think it will be good to enable uploading archived file (like `tar.gz` or `zip`). We contine to improve the way to upload the data.
I agree, uploading a `tar.gz` archive would be helpful as well.

issue.title: how to label for sentence pairs?

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
For the semantic similarity of two sentence.  Is there any possible to label sentence pairs？
Using '，' to separate two sentence seems possible, but it not very beautiful. How to using two line to show the sentence ?

body: So is there a consensus on the format of the JSON file? I can update the parser as needed.  Also, is the separate radio button an acceptable way to implement this functionality in the UI, or would we want to auto-detect based on file extension?  Finally, if the user uploads a zip or tar file should it be expected that the archive contains a single file and if so, what is the format of that file, CSV, JSON, both?

issue.title: Adding in linebreaks filters

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
I'm attempting to add in linebreak filters to allow newlines to be rendered within documents to complement #17 however I can't seem to get them working.

I've identified the line which inserts the document text to be line 34 of document_classification.html
https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/blob/master/app/server/templates/annotation/document_classification.html#L34

However modifying it to `[[ docs[pageNumber].text|linebreaks ]]` does not produce the desired effect.

On a side note I am not very familiar with Django, what is the significance of the double square-bracket syntax? I have not seen it in any Django examples.  Aren't variables typically inserted with double curly-brackets in templates?

body:
@Zerthick, thanks for your advice. We had a discussion about your request and I will share it with you. 

* So is there a consensus on the format of the JSON file? 
  * Yes, we want to support the JSON file. 

* Also, is the separate radio button an acceptable way to implement this functionality in the UI, or would we want to auto-detect based on file extension? 
  * The radio button is a great idea, we will accept it.

* Finally, if the user uploads a zip or tar file should it be expected that the archive contains a single file and if so, what is the format of that file, CSV, JSON, both?
  * Right now, we want to support the JSON file first. After we finish the JSON support part, we can open a new issue to talk about supporting the zip or tar file. 

---

* As for the JSON format. You mentioned JSON format such as:
```
[
    "Document 1 text",
    "Document 2 text"
]
```
This format is pretty the same with the txt format file. In such case, we recommend you use the txt format to upload your file. And in order to make full use of JSON format, we set the JSON format like `demo1.json` below:
```
{'text': 'this is the first text'}
{'text': 'this is the second text'}
```
The key should be set as `text`, and the value is the document we want to annotate. The reason why we set this format is that we want to support the #11 Import labeled dataset in the future. In such case, we can import JSON like `demo2.json` below:
```
{'text': 'this is the first text', 'label': xxxx }
{'text': 'this is the second text', 'label', xxxx}
```
The label format will be different regarding the project/task. But first we want to support the JSON format like `demo1.json`.

---

The JSON file should work in three project/task (sequence labeling, document classification, sequence to sequence). But for the sequence labeling task, the document is supposed contain no newline. Becasue this will cause the UI changed in the sequence labeling anotation page. For other two tasks, it is ok that the document contains newline. 

I upload two demo json file for test, feel free to use it.
[test_json_NER.json](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Fhr3xBmfdUbtLko9Prd-ZtsUQl6SWERA)
[test_json_NER_newline.json](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1FdSrY_GADnGiA-wPZnpleZIntkkqQyYo)

If you have any question, let me know :)

@Zerthick Thanks for your advice. Outputting spacy JSON format is a good idea, we also want to support this feature. But as the input JSON format, we want to make it as simple as possible to make sure processing one line each time. And if we use the totally same spacy JSON format, we have to change the backend model, which is not we want. 

Because our JSON format is very simple, it is easy to write a script to convert spacy JSON annotated file to our format. And after annotating the file in doccano, you can download the spacy JSON format data. This will become a closed cycle. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10768193/48526715-033b7200-e8cc-11e8-9422-b4bd27979e84.png)

As for the convert script, you implement by yourself and PR to us. If there is no such convert script after we complete the JSON support feature, we will offer such a script. #15

Ok, in that case I'd suggest making your format a valid JSON list, as it will be easier to generate and load in python scripts, so something like:

```json
[
    {"text": "this is the first text"},
    {"text": "this is the second text"}
]
```

In such a format, we have to load the whole JSON file at once. If the file has big size, this would use a lot of memory. That's why we want to make the JSON format as simple as possible to read the file line by line, which can avoid big memory usage.

Ok makes sense, I rework my parser accordingly.  How would you like to handle multiple labels?

Would you do something like:
```json
{"text": "this is the first text", "label": ["label1", "label2"] }
```
Or something like:
```json
{"text": "this is the first text", "label1": true, "label2": true }
```
Or something else?
As for the label format, we will discuss it later.  But there should be a `label` key contains all label information, which is like the first example you list.
Understood, I'll just work on parsing the `text` key for now then.

issue.title: iss17: support for uploading json file

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
#17 
* Add json upload button and format value in `dataset_upload.html` 
* Change `views.py` for processing json file
* Add test case for json upload feature

body: Hi @Zerthick, thanks for your advice. Right now you can upload json file to doccano. Next we will work on the #27 to make linebreak possible.
